qas.question: In what space at the V&A is the Architecture Gallery located?
What is found at Room 128a of the Victoria & Albert Museum?
Who designed rooms 128 and 128a at the V&A Museum?
Where was the Royal Institute's Drawing and Archives Collections located originally?
What part of the V&A was the Royal Institute's Drawing and Archives collection moved to?
What space at the V&A is the Architecture Gallery forbidden?
What is not found at Room 128a of the Victoria & Albert Museum?
Who destroyed rooms 128 and 128a at the V&A Museum?
Where was the Royal Institute's Drawing and Archives Collections banned originally?
What part of the V&A was the Royal Institute's Drawing and Archives collection avoided from?

context: In 2004, the two institutions created the Architecture Gallery (<a0_0><b5_0>Room 128<b5_0/><a0_0/>) at the V&A showing artefacts from the collections of both institutions, this was the first permanent gallery devoted to architecture in the UK. The adjacent <a1_0><b6_0>Architecture Exhibition Space<b6_0/><a1_0/> (Room 128a) is used for temporary displays related to architecture. Both spaces were designed by <a2_0><b7_0>Gareth Hoskins Architects<b7_0/><a2_0/>. At the same time the RIBA Library Drawing and Archives Collections moved from <a3_0><b8_0>21 Portman Place<b8_0/><a3_0/> to new facilities in <a4_0><b9_0>the Henry Cole Wing<b9_0/><a4_0/> at the V&A. Under the Partnership new study rooms were opened where members of the public could view items from the RIBA and V&A architectural collections under the supervision of curatorial staff. These and the nearby education room were designed by Wright & Wright Architects.
